ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze academic readings in this class. I enjoyed discussing them and learned a lot from my classmates' perspectives on them during discussions. I developed my writing and planning skills and improved my ability to write academic essays and research papers in this class.

Taking this course I was able to more in depth analyze history and our place as people in analyzing history. It was interesting to read so many excerpts to better understand different perspectives on the " other" and archives.
I developed numerous writing skills, specifically evidence based analysis and the proper way to write a claim.

A brilliant deep dive into understanding the systematic and powerful nature of knowledge archival, from perspectives of inequality and opportunity alike. This class offered a great way to ingest information from a knowledgeable vantage, and how to portray information in a well-organized manner in writing and research.
i learned how to structure and outline my arguments in a paper, and efficiently read long readings

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this class are the class discussions and the checkpoints assigned by the professor which made the process of writing the research paper more streamlined and less daunting. A weakness of this class is that little time was spent teaching writing techniques. Instead, we had to rely on past knowledge when crafting our essays. I would recommend that more class time be dedicated to teaching aspects of writing that we can incorporate into our essays.
greatest focus was on the historical/social context of the course with writing used as a tool to explore it, little emphasis on how to improve writing or essay techniques

The course was very well organized with extremely interesting topics and talking points. One weakness was that sometimes the text we read were long and a little confusing but eventually I was able to understand what I was reading.

One strength would be the dicussions that took place in class. I enjoyed reading and hearing everyones opinions about the topic.
One weakness would be the amount of time to receive feedback on my essays. I feel like I could not see what I did wrong on some essays and would make the same mistake on the next essay so I lost points without being corrected the first time.

The assignments could have been better scheduled, or held to their original dates and told of further in advance more. We were often left to question the dates we were given as they were soon in the future from the assignment being given, as though we were told a week too late: this lead to the pushing of deadlines, which led to projects coming up against the end of the semester.

the essay writing, readings, and discussions in class were not very well-connected. i found it difficult to stay engaged with the readings because they were dry and long, and the discussions during class were very hard to keep up with because it was essentially the same people talking. feedback on essays were also very slow, and it was hard to understand what was expected of me in this class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to be challenged to be a better writer and reader.
I would recommend this course to students who prefer the discussion-based format of seminar classes and want to improve their writing skills through writing academic essays and a research paper.
I would recommend the course to another student. It helped intertwine my love of history into an English class. I was not only able to improve my knowledge of writing but also history.
I would recommend this course to students interested in this topic specifically. Some people would not like the stuff we learned but I liked it.
Absolutely, though I might push them away from the 9AM time slot its earlier than you might think.

if you have a strong interest in learning about archives and colonialism, the texts were great at diving in deeper and inciting interesting discussions. if you aren't comfortable with deep discussions and synthesizing across texts, this course can feel heavy and difficult really quickly.
